conclusion: To determine the work done by the gas on the surroundings during the cyclic process, we need to calculate the work done in each of the three processes: A→B, B→C, and C→A.
The work done by the gas in a process is given by the area under the curve in a P-V diagram.
Process A→B is an isochoric (constant volume) process.
Pressure changes from P_A = 1 × 10^5 Pa to P_B = 4 × 10^5 Pa.

premise: Work done in an isochoric process is zero because W = P ΔV and ΔV = 0.

conclusion: Process B→C is an isobaric (constant pressure) process.
Volume changes from V_B = 2 L to V_C = 5 L.

premise: Work done in an isobaric process is given by W = P ΔV.

conclusion: Process C→A is an isochoric (constant volume) process.
Pressure changes from P_C = 4 × 10^5 Pa to P_A = 1 × 10^5 Pa.

premise: Work done in an isochoric process is zero because W = P ΔV and ΔV = 0.
The total work done by the gas during the cyclic process is the sum of the work done in each process.
